overview_of_class: The story of modern cosmology (the study of the universe) is the story of science itself. The story of modern cosmology is the story of science itself. From the positions and movement of planets to the shining of the stars and the glow of the earliest light in the universe, our search for our place in the cosmos developed scientific methods that drove us to new heights of discovery. See the world through different eyes and learn about the mysteries revealed by X-rays, radio waves and the recently discovered gravitational waves from colliding black holes. Explore the lives and deaths of stars as we uncover the most astounding facts about the universe. Take a tour of the dark side as we explore dark matter, dark energy, and black holes. Travel virtually back in time 99.997% of the way to the Big Bang itself to see a "baby picture" of the universe. From its origin to its ultimate destiny, we will explore the scientific story of our universe - what we know and how we know it. The course will include a expert-led trip to the historic Northwestern Dearborn Observatory for night sky observing (weather permitting), in class demonstrations and computer interactive explorations. This course is designed for non-science majors and has no math prerequisite.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will master basic astronomical and physical principles that build a "how do we know what we know" foundation, learning to apply these concepts to features of the universe. They will be able to discuss the big bang theory, comparing its supporting observations and predictions to those made by other theories. Through their acquired understanding, students will be able to contextualize scientific discoveries reported in the media.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture, discussion, iPad and computer guided interactives, short writing assignments, in class demonstrations, field trips.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
1. Midterm Exam
2. Final Exam
3. Quizzes (in class and take home)
4. Short writing assignments.

Each of these components will be worth 25% of the total score.
